21. If we link our planes together like this,
and so allow one to glide into another
slithering like a twisting adder.
Do not abandon fading into the distance,
for the background regions must be sound.
We should avoid having Mountains, Hills, Dikes
in a strong dark clash against soft light;
rather, the benefit comes with half color.
right-middleTo make the planes hang together properly, the Landscape should fade well into the distance.
right-middleNot placing dark planes or others against the light.

22. One should not place Houses in the foreground,
unless wishing to tell a story
constructed from half Landscape and half figures;
One should work according to the subject, but otherwise avoid
a heavy composition, which smothers the space.
Yet without too much abundance, let the grounds
As is fitting, bloom with some beautiful greenery.
right-middleLarge houses will be unbecoming in the foreground, though some beautiful greenery will, only not too abundant.

23. We should imitate, in a wise and informed manner,
great variety, in colors as in life,
for it offers a great and laudable beauty.
Yet in this regard we must avoid
imprudently adding Cities, Houses, Mountains,
or other objects too abundantly.
Indeed, this hinders the enjoyment of a balanced composition,
even if it is in the distance.
right-middleToo many Mountains, Cities, Houses or background elements are unsightly.

24. The Italians painting Landscapes
are few but artful, almost without peer,
and in large part show views
into a single perspective along with very sturdy
Planes and Cities–indeed, whatever they display.
Above Tintoretto is the magnificent
Titian, whose woodcut will teach us
what we see from that Painter of Brescia.
right-middleThe Italians, few in number but excellent Landscapists, most often create a single perspective view, and are excellent at sturdy grounds and buildings.

25. In regard to these, I wish to boast proudly
of the well-colored and ingenious compositions
in the paintings and prints of Bruegel.
Here, for example in the peaked rocky Alps,
he teaches us to depict views
deep into a dizzying ravine,
steep crags and cloud-kissing Pine trees,
Distant vistas, and rushing streams.
right-middleThe Landscapes and prints of Bruegel as examples.
